intro: Galium obliquum var. leucophaeum, commonly known as the white-leaf bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It features slender, ascending stems that are often hairy and can grow up to 30 centimeters in height. The leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic, and have a distinctive white or pale green underside, giving the plant its common name. It produces small, greenish-white flowers in clusters during late spring to early summer. This variety is closely related to other species in the Rubiaceae family and is often found in moist, shaded woodlands.
